import React, { useState } from 'react'; import SpectrumBar from './SpectrumBar'; import { getAbsorbedColor, getObservedColor, getColorBand } from '../utils/colorUtils'; const WavelengthVisualizer = ({ initialWavelength = 450 }) => { const [wavelength, setWavelength] = useState(initialWavelength); const [mode, setMode] = useState('ideal'); const [showInfo, setShowInfo] = useState(false); const handleWavelengthChange = (e) => { const value = parseInt(e.target.value) || 0; if (value >= 380 && value <= 780) { setWavelength(value); } }; const absorbedColor = getAbsorbedColor(wavelength); const observedColor = getObservedColor(wavelength, mode); const colorBand = getColorBand(wavelength); return (

üåà Wavelength Absorption ‚Üí Observed Color

Enter a wavelength to see what color is absorbed and what color the compound appears

{/* Input Controls */}
Mode:
{/* Spectrum Bar */} {/* Color Swatches */}

Absorbed Color

Band: {colorBand || 'N/A'}

{absorbedColor}

Observed Color (Appears)

The compound appears this color

{observedColor}

{/* Info Toggle */}
{showInfo && (

Ideal Mode: Uses fixed complementary color relationships based on the color wheel. For example, if a compound absorbs blue light, it appears orange (blue's complement).

Real Mode: Calculates the complementary color using RGB inversion, which approximates how human perception would see the reflected wavelengths. This often gives more natural-looking results.

üí° In spectroscopy, the color you see is the color that is NOT absorbed‚Äîit's the wavelengths that are reflected or transmitted!

)}
); }; export default WavelengthVisualizer;
